title: 107_hr970
content: The Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 is amended to allocate $25,000,000 for fiscal year 2002 and subsequent years for the implementation of an Effective Prevention Program. Subparts and sections are redesignated accordingly. SEC. 4121. COMPREHENSIVE PREVENTION TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE GRANTS. The Secretary is authorized to provide grants to States for prevention programs meeting high scientific standards. States must submit a plan detailing grant selection criteria, funding only well-documented programs, disseminating research-based materials, and providing technical assistance. The State educational agency will provide technical assistance for evaluating, selecting, and implementing prevention programs. They will evaluate program implementation, ensure compliance with requirements, and ensure funds supplement other available resources. Additional criteria may be required by the Secretary. SEC. 4122. RESERVATIONS AND ALLOCATIONS. The Secretary reserves and allocates funds among States for implementing programs under this subpart. If a State does not meet plan requirements, funds are reallocated to other States. Funds must be used for program implementation. SEC. 4123. DISTRIBUTION OF FUNDS. Each State educational agency receiving funds under this subpart must provide competitive grants to local educational agencies. Priority is given to agencies with demonstrated need, grants must support startup costs for prevention plans, and awards should be distributed equitably across different regions and school types. The State educational agency must distribute awards equitably across different geographic regions and school types. Up to 5 percent of funds can be used for administrative expenses and informing local agencies about prevention approaches. "SEC. 4124. LOCAL AWARDS." To be eligible for a subgrant, a local educational agency must submit an application and a plan demonstrating how it will meet program requirements. The grant funds must be used for implementing prevention programs based on reliable research, addressing various aspects of children's health, and providing developmentally appropriate interventions to improve student performance. The subgrant program requirements include addressing the mental, emotional, social, and physical health of children and adolescents, using developmentally appropriate activities and interventions, improving cognitive, affective, and behavioral skills, ensuring active engagement of participants, involving parents, educators, and professionals in planning, providing staff training, setting measurable goals, and utilizing external technical support. The subgrant program requires addressing the mental, emotional, social, and physical health of children and adolescents through developmentally appropriate activities, interventions, and skills improvement. It also involves active engagement of participants, parent and professional involvement, staff training, setting measurable goals, utilizing external technical support, and coordinating resources for comprehensive prevention efforts.
